**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Let me guess, you've got Facebook albums full of photos. You have photos on your computer desktop, on your mobile phone, on your bedroom wall. You see photos in magazines and newspapers, on the side of buses, and of course, in your family albums. We take photos for granted in a major way. But, creating a picture that looked exactly like the person or thing that you were photographing wasn't always obvious. In fact, in the past, it was a big mystery. How could you, in essence, take your reflection in the mirror and freeze it in there? In the 9th century, the Arab scientist Alhazen had come up with the idea of using the camera obscura, which was literally a dark room, or box, with a single, small hole in one side that let light through. This would project the image outside into the wall inside. During the Renaissance, artists like Leonardo DaVinci used this method to introduce 3-D scenes onto a flat plane so that they could copy things, like perspective, more easily. In 1724, Johann Heinrich Schultz discovered that exposing certain silver compounds to light altered their appearance and left marks wherever the light touched. Essentially, Schultz found a way to record the images that Alhazen was able to project, but only for a little while. Schultz's images disappeared soon after he had made them. It wasn't until 1839 that people figured out how to project images onto light-sensitive surfaces that would retain the image after exposure, and thus, photography was born. At that point, it was mostly two inventors who fought for the best way to make photos. One was British scientist Henry Fox Talbot, whose calotype process used paper and allowed many copies to be made from a single negative. The other inventor, Louis Daguerre, was an artist and chemist in France. He developed something called a daguerreotype, which used a silvered plate and which produced a sharper image. But the daguerreotype could only make positive images so copies had to be made by taking another photo. In the end, the daguerreotype won out as the first commercially successful photographic process mostly because the government made it freely available to the public. So now that photography was available, getting a picture of yourself would be a snap, right? Well, not exactly! This process still required a whole dark room at the location of the photograph, which was a big hassle. Picture the early photographers lugging enormous trailers with all their equipment wherever they wanted to take a picture. Not only that, but the early processes had extremely long exposure times. To get a good photo, you would have to stand perfectly still for up to two minutes! This led to development of inventions like the head holder, a wire frame that would hide behind you while supporting your head. It's also why you don't see people smiling in early photographs. It's not that life was that bad, it was just hard to keep a steady grin for more than a few seconds, so people opted for a straight-faced look. And then George Eastman came along. Eastman believed that everyone should have access to photography, and he spent many late nights mixing chemicals in his mother's kitchen to try to achieve a dry plate photographic process. This would allow exposed negatives to be stored and developed later at a more convenient place instead of carting those dark rooms, necessary for wet plates, around. After starting a business, which initially made dry plates, Eastman eventually discovered plastic roll film that would fit in hand-held, inexpensive cameras. These cameras sold by the millions under the tag line, "You push the button, we do the rest." While Eastman was largely responsible for making photography a universal pastime, even he could not have dreamed of the ways photography had since shaped the world. It's now estimated that over 380 billion photographs are taken each year. That's more photographs each day than were taken in the first hundred years after photography was invented. Say cheese!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who came up with the idea of camera obscura?
Options: A. Alhazen, B. Johann Heinrich Schultz, C. Henry Fox Talbot, D. Louis Daguerre
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is credited with the idea of using the camera obscura in the 9th century to project images onto a surface? Options: A. Leonardo DaVinci, B. Alhazen, C. Johann Heinrich Schultz, D. Henry Fox Talbot Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the primary limitation of Johann Heinrich Schultz's discovery in 1724 regarding the exposure of silver compounds to light? Options: A. The images were too small to be useful, B. The images were too blurry to be recognizable, C. The images disappeared soon after exposure to light, D. The images were not reproducible Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the main difference between Henry Fox Talbot's calotype process and Louis Daguerre's daguerreotype in terms of image reproduction? Options: A. The type of paper used for printing, B. The ability to produce multiple copies from a single negative, C. The exposure time required for image capture, D. The size of the images produced Correct Option: B
Question 4: Why did the daguerreotype win out as the first commercially successful photographic process in the 19th century? Options: A. It produced sharper images than the calotype process, B. It allowed multiple copies to be made from a single negative, C. The government made it freely available to the public, D. It was more widely adopted by artists Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the primary challenge faced by early photographers in terms of capturing images of people? Options: A. The equipment was too heavy to transport, B. The exposure times were too long, requiring subjects to remain still, C. The chemicals were too expensive to use, D. The subjects were too uncooperative to photograph Correct Option: B
Question 6: What invention helped to alleviate the problem of long exposure times in early photography by providing support for the subject's head? Options: A. The head holder, B. The dry plate photographic process, C. The camera obscura, D. The tripod Correct Option: A
Question 7: How did George Eastman contribute to the development of photography in the late 19th century? Options: A. He invented the camera obscura, B. He developed the daguerreotype, C. He discovered plastic roll film and made photography more accessible, D. He improved the calotype process Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the impact of George Eastman's innovations on photography in terms of its accessibility and popularity? Options: A. Photography became more expensive and exclusive, B. Photography became more accessible and widespread, C. Photography became more time-consuming and labor-intensive, D. Photography became less popular and widely used Correct Option: B
Question 9: How has photography changed the world since its invention in terms of its widespread use and popularity? Options: A. It has become a niche hobby for a select few, B. It has become a universal pastime with billions of photographs taken each year, C. It has remained largely unchanged since its invention, D. It has become a forgotten art form Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is estimated to be the number of photographs taken each year, reflecting the widespread use and popularity of photography? Options: A. Over 100 million, B. Over 1 billion, C. Over 380 billion, D. Over 1 trillion Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Let me guess, you've got Facebook albums full of photos. You have photos on your computer desktop, on your mobile phone, on your bedroom wall. You see photos in magazines and newspapers, on the side of buses, and of course, in your family albums. We take photos for granted in a major way. But, creating a picture that looked exactly like the person or thing that you were photographing wasn't always obvious. In fact, in the past, it was a big mystery. How could you, in essence, take your reflection in the mirror and freeze it in there? In the 9th century, the Arab scientist Alhazen had come up with the idea of using the camera obscura, which was literally a dark room, or box, with a single, small hole in one side that let light through. This would project the image outside into the wall inside. During the Renaissance, artists like Leonardo DaVinci used this method to introduce 3-D scenes onto a flat plane so that they could copy things, like perspective, more easily. In 1724, Johann Heinrich Schultz discovered that exposing certain silver compounds to light altered their appearance and left marks wherever the light touched. Essentially, Schultz found a way to record the images that Alhazen was able to project, but only for a little while. Schultz's images disappeared soon after he had made them. It wasn't until 1839 that people figured out how to project images onto light-sensitive surfaces that would retain the image after exposure, and thus, photography was born. At that point, it was mostly two inventors who fought for the best way to make photos. One was British scientist Henry Fox Talbot, whose calotype process used paper and allowed many copies to be made from a single negative. The other inventor, Louis Daguerre, was an artist and chemist in France. He developed something called a daguerreotype, which used a silvered plate and which produced a sharper image. But the daguerreotype could only make positive images so copies had to be made by taking another photo. In the end, the daguerreotype won out as the first commercially successful photographic process mostly because the government made it freely available to the public. So now that photography was available, getting a picture of yourself would be a snap, right? Well, not exactly! This process still required a whole dark room at the location of the photograph, which was a big hassle. Picture the early photographers lugging enormous trailers with all their equipment wherever they wanted to take a picture. Not only that, but the early processes had extremely long exposure times. To get a good photo, you would have to stand perfectly still for up to two minutes! This led to development of inventions like the head holder, a wire frame that would hide behind you while supporting your head. It's also why you don't see people smiling in early photographs. It's not that life was that bad, it was just hard to keep a steady grin for more than a few seconds, so people opted for a straight-faced look. And then George Eastman came along. Eastman believed that everyone should have access to photography, and he spent many late nights mixing chemicals in his mother's kitchen to try to achieve a dry plate photographic process. This would allow exposed negatives to be stored and developed later at a more convenient place instead of carting those dark rooms, necessary for wet plates, around. After starting a business, which initially made dry plates, Eastman eventually discovered plastic roll film that would fit in hand-held, inexpensive cameras. These cameras sold by the millions under the tag line, "You push the button, we do the rest." While Eastman was largely responsible for making photography a universal pastime, even he could not have dreamed of the ways photography had since shaped the world. It's now estimated that over 380 billion photographs are taken each year. That's more photographs each day than were taken in the first hundred years after photography was invented. Say cheese!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who discovered that exposing certain silver compounds to light altered their appearance?
Options: A. Alhazen, B. Johann Heinrich Schultz, C. Henry Fox Talbot, D. Louis Daguerre
Correct Option: B

In 1724, Johann Heinrich Schultz discovered that exposing certain silver compounds to light altered their appearance and left marks wherever the light touched. Essentially, Schultz found a way to record the images that Alhazen was able to project, but only for a little while. Schultz's images disappeared soon after he had made them. At that point, it was mostly two inventors who fought for the best way to make photos. One was British scientist Henry Fox Talbot, whose calotype process used paper and allowed many copies to be made from a single negative. The other inventor, Louis Daguerre, was an artist and chemist in France. He developed something called a daguerreotype, which used a silvered plate and which produced a sharper image. Picture the early photographers lugging enormous trailers with all their equipment wherever they wanted to take a picture. Not only that, but the early processes had extremely long exposure times. To get a good photo, you would have to stand perfectly still for up to two minutes! This led to development of inventions like the head holder, a wire frame that would hide behind you while supporting your head. It's also why you don't see people smiling in early photographs. It's not that life was that bad, it was just hard to keep a steady grin for more than a few seconds, so people opted for a straight-faced look. And then George Eastman came along. Eastman believed that everyone should have access to photography, and he spent many late nights mixing chemicals in his mother's kitchen to try to achieve a dry plate photographic process. This would allow exposed negatives to be stored and developed later at a more convenient place instead of carting those dark rooms, necessary for wet plates, around. After starting a business, which initially made dry plates, Eastman eventually discovered plastic roll film that would fit in hand-held, inexpensive cameras. These cameras sold by the millions under the tag line, "You push the button, we do the rest." While Eastman was largely responsible for making photography a universal pastime, even he could not have dreamed of the ways photography had since shaped the world. It's now estimated that over 380 billion photographs are taken each year. That's more photographs each day than were taken in the first hundred years after photography was invented. Say cheese!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why don't people smile in early photographs?
Options: A. Life was hard, so photography was reflecting that truth, B. People didn't understand what was happening, so photographs were capturing their confusion, C. Until about 100 years after photography was invented, it wasn't fashionable to smile in public, D. Exposure times were long, and it was difficult to hold a grin
Correct Option: D

To get a good photo, you would have to stand perfectly still for up to two minutes! This led to development of inventions like the head holder, a wire frame that would hide behind you while supporting your head. It's also why you don't see people smiling in early photographs. It's not that life was that bad, it was just hard to keep a steady grin for more than a few seconds, so people opted for a straight-faced look. And then George Eastman came along. Eastman believed that everyone should have access to photography, and he spent many late nights mixing chemicals in his mother's kitchen to try to achieve a dry plate photographic process. This would allow exposed negatives to be stored and developed later at a more convenient place instead of carting those dark rooms, necessary for wet plates, around. After starting a business, which initially made dry plates, Eastman eventually discovered plastic roll film that would fit in hand-held, inexpensive cameras. These cameras sold by the millions under the tag line, "You push the button, we do the rest." While Eastman was largely responsible for making photography a universal pastime, even he could not have dreamed of the ways photography had since shaped the world. It's now estimated that over 380 billion photographs are taken each year. That's more photographs each day than were taken in the first hundred years after photography was invented. Say cheese!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who is largely responsible for making photography a universal pastime?
Options: A. George Eastman, B. Bill Gates, C. William (Bill) Redington Hewlett, D. Dave Packard
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is credited with the idea of using the camera obscura in the 9th century to project images onto a surface? Options: A. Leonardo DaVinci, B. Alhazen, C. Johann Heinrich Schultz, D. Henry Fox Talbot Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the primary limitation of Johann Heinrich Schultz's discovery in 1724 regarding the exposure of silver compounds to light? Options: A. The images were too small to be useful, B. The images were too blurry to be recognizable, C. The images disappeared soon after exposure to light, D. The images were not reproducible Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the main difference between Henry Fox Talbot's calotype process and Louis Daguerre's daguerreotype in terms of image reproduction? Options: A. The type of paper used for printing, B. The ability to produce multiple copies from a single negative, C. The exposure time required for image capture, D. The size of the images produced Correct Option: B
Question 4: Why did the daguerreotype win out as the first commercially successful photographic process in the 19th century? Options: A. It produced sharper images than the calotype process, B. It allowed multiple copies to be made from a single negative, C. The government made it freely available to the public, D. It was more widely adopted by artists Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the primary challenge faced by early photographers in terms of capturing images of people? Options: A. The equipment was too heavy to transport, B. The exposure times were too long, requiring subjects to remain still, C. The chemicals were too expensive to use, D. The subjects were too uncooperative to photograph Correct Option: B
Question 6: What invention helped to alleviate the problem of long exposure times in early photography by providing support for the subject's head? Options: A. The head holder, B. The dry plate photographic process, C. The camera obscura, D. The tripod Correct Option: A
Question 7: How did George Eastman contribute to the development of photography in the late 19th century? Options: A. He invented the camera obscura, B. He developed the daguerreotype, C. He discovered plastic roll film and made photography more accessible, D. He improved the calotype process Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the impact of George Eastman's innovations on photography in terms of its accessibility and popularity? Options: A. Photography became more expensive and exclusive, B. Photography became more accessible and widespread, C. Photography became more time-consuming and labor-intensive, D. Photography became less popular and widely used Correct Option: B
Question 9: How has photography changed the world since its invention in terms of its widespread use and popularity? Options: A. It has become a niche hobby for a select few, B. It has become a universal pastime with billions of photographs taken each year, C. It has remained largely unchanged since its invention, D. It has become a forgotten art form Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is estimated to be the number of photographs taken each year, reflecting the widespread use and popularity of photography? Options: A. Over 100 million, B. Over 1 billion, C. Over 380 billion, D. Over 1 trillion Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Every cell in your body is separated from those around it by its outermost layer, its membrane. A cell membrane must be both sturdy and flexible. Imagine a membrane made of metal - great at keeping the cell's guts inside, but horrible at letting materials flow in and out. But a membrane made of fishnet stocking would go too far in the opposite direction - leaky, but easily torn. So, the ideal membrane falls somewhere in the middle. Over the past few centuries, we've learned a lot about the way membranes work. The tale starts in the late 1800's when, according to legend, a German woman named Agnes Pockels was doing dishes. Her observation, that not all detergents dissolve grease in the same way, piqued her curiosity, so she made careful measurements of the size of soapy films that formed on the surface of a metal tray filled with water. Later, in the 1920's, GE scientists Irving Langmuir and Katharine Blodgett reexamined the problem with a more elaborate contraption and found that those tiny slicks were in fact a single layer of oil molecules. Each oil molecule has one side that loves water and floats on the surface, and one side that loathes water and protrudes into the air. So what does it have to do with cell membranes? Well, at the turn of the 20th century, chemists Charles Overton and Hans Meyer demonstrated that the cell membrane is composed of substances that, like oil, have a water-loving part and a water-loathing part. We now call these substances lipids. In 1925, two scientists, Evert Gorter and Francois Grendel, pushed our understanding further. They designed an experiment meant to test whether cell membranes are made of only one layer of lipids, a monolayer, or two layers stacked on top of one another, called a bilayer. Gorter and Grendel drew blood from a dog, a sheep, a rabbit, a goat, a guinea pig, and human volunteers. From each of these samples, they extracted all the lipids from all the red blood cells and placed a few drops of this extract on a tray of water. True to form, the lipids, like oil, spread out into a monolayer, whose size Gorter and Grendel could measure. If they compared the surface area of that monolayer to the surface area to the intact red blood cells, they'd be able to tell whether the red blood cell membrane is one or two layers thick. To understand the design of their experiment, imagine looking down at a sandwich. If you measure the surface area of what you see, you'll get the dimensions of a single slice of bread even though there are two slices, one stacked perfectly atop the other. But, if you open the sandwich and place the two slices side by side, you get twice the surface area. The Gorter and Grendel experiment is basically the same idea. The open sandwich is the monolayer formed by extracted cellular lipids spreading out into a sheet. The closed sandwich is the intact red blood cell membrane. Low and behold, they observed a two-to-one ratio, proving beyond the shadow of a doubt that a cell membrane is a bilayer, which when unstacked, yields a monolayer twice its size. So almost 30 years before the double-helix structure of DNA was elucidated, a single experiment involving fancy versions of household materials enabled deep insight into the basic architecture of the cell.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Every cell in your body is separated from the cells around it by its outer most layer called the:
Options: A. Cell bilayer, B. Mitochondria, C. Cell membrane, D. Pseudostratified epithelial
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary function of a cell membrane in the human body? Options: A. To synthesize proteins, B. To store genetic information, C. To separate the cell from its surroundings and regulate the flow of materials, D. To provide structural support to the cell Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what inspired Agnes Pockels to investigate the properties of soapy films? Options: A. Her work with GE scientists Irving Langmuir and Katharine Blodgett, B. Her observation that not all detergents dissolve grease in the same way while doing dishes, C. Her study of the cell membrane structure, D. Her interest in the double-helix structure of DNA Correct Option: B
Question 3: What would be the consequence of having a cell membrane that is too rigid, like one made of metal? Options: A. It would allow for easy passage of materials in and out of the cell, B. It would provide excellent protection to the cell's contents, C. It would hinder the flow of materials in and out of the cell, D. It would have no effect on the cell's functioning Correct Option: C
Question 4: How do lipids, the primary components of cell membranes, interact with water? Options: A. They are entirely hydrophobic (water-repelling), B. They are entirely hydrophilic (water-attracting), C. They have both hydrophobic and hydrophilic parts, D. They are neutral and do not interact with water Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the main objective of Evert Gorter and Francois Grendel's experiment in 1925? Options: A. To demonstrate the fluidity of cell membranes, B. To determine the structure of DNA, C. To test whether cell membranes are made of one layer (monolayer) or two layers (bilayer) of lipids, D. To study the function of detergents in cell membrane structure Correct Option: C
Question 6: In Gorter and Grendel's experiment, what was the observed ratio of the surface area of the monolayer formed by extracted cellular lipids to the surface area of the intact red blood cell membrane? Options: A. 1:1, B. 2:1, C. 3:1, D. 4:1 Correct Option: B
Question 7: What can be inferred about the structure of a cell membrane based on the results of Gorter and Grendel's experiment? Options: A. It is a single layer of lipids, B. It is a bilayer of lipids, C. It is a triple layer of lipids, D. It is a complex structure composed of multiple layers of lipids and proteins Correct Option: B
Question 8: How does the structure of a cell membrane, as revealed by Gorter and Grendel's experiment, relate to its function? Options: A. The bilayer structure provides rigidity and support to the cell, B. The bilayer structure allows for easy passage of materials in and out of the cell, C. The bilayer structure provides a balance between stability and fluidity, enabling the cell membrane to regulate the flow of materials, D. The bilayer structure has no relation to the cell membrane's function Correct Option: C
Question 9: What can be said about the significance of Gorter and Grendel's experiment in the context of scientific discovery? Options: A. It was a minor contribution to the understanding of cell membrane structure, B. It was a groundbreaking experiment that provided deep insight into the basic architecture of the cell, C. It was a failed experiment that did not yield any meaningful results, D. It was a redundant experiment that confirmed existing knowledge about cell membranes Correct Option: B
Question 10: How does the discovery of the cell membrane's bilayer structure, as revealed by Gorter and Grendel's experiment, compare to other significant scientific discoveries in the field of biology? Options: A. It was a relatively minor discovery compared to the elucidation of the double-helix structure of DNA, B. It was a major discovery that preceded and laid the groundwork for the elucidation of the double-helix structure of DNA, C. It was a discovery that contradicted the existing understanding of cell membrane structure, D. It was a discovery that had no impact on the field of biology Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although the question wording is not identical, the intent and content of Question 1 align with the ground truth MCQ. Both questions focus on the cell membrane, and the correct option (C) in Question 1 mentions the cell membrane's role in separating the cell from its surroundings, which is related to the ground truth MCQ's definition of the cell membrane as the outermost layer that separates the cell from those around it.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 2

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. So almost 30 years before the double-helix structure of DNA was elucidated, a single experiment involving fancy versions of household materials enabled deep insight into the basic architecture of the cell.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What were Gorter and Grendel trying to prove?
Options: A. Red blood cells are constructed as a bilayer, B. Every species of animal has a distinct monolayer or bilayer construction of their red blood cells., C. When a red blood cell bilayer is "unstacked," it yields a monolayer twice its size, D. Both A and C
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary function of a cell membrane in the human body? Options: A. To synthesize proteins, B. To store genetic information, C. To separate the cell from its surroundings and regulate the flow of materials, D. To provide structural support to the cell Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what inspired Agnes Pockels to investigate the properties of soapy films? Options: A. Her work with GE scientists Irving Langmuir and Katharine Blodgett, B. Her observation that not all detergents dissolve grease in the same way while doing dishes, C. Her study of the cell membrane structure, D. Her interest in the double-helix structure of DNA Correct Option: B
Question 3: What would be the consequence of having a cell membrane that is too rigid, like one made of metal? Options: A. It would allow for easy passage of materials in and out of the cell, B. It would provide excellent protection to the cell's contents, C. It would hinder the flow of materials in and out of the cell, D. It would have no effect on the cell's functioning Correct Option: C
Question 4: How do lipids, the primary components of cell membranes, interact with water? Options: A. They are entirely hydrophobic (water-repelling), B. They are entirely hydrophilic (water-attracting), C. They have both hydrophobic and hydrophilic parts, D. They are neutral and do not interact with water Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the main objective of Evert Gorter and Francois Grendel's experiment in 1925? Options: A. To demonstrate the fluidity of cell membranes, B. To determine the structure of DNA, C. To test whether cell membranes are made of one layer (monolayer) or two layers (bilayer) of lipids, D. To study the function of detergents in cell membrane structure Correct Option: C
Question 6: In Gorter and Grendel's experiment, what was the observed ratio of the surface area of the monolayer formed by extracted cellular lipids to the surface area of the intact red blood cell membrane? Options: A. 1:1, B. 2:1, C. 3:1, D. 4:1 Correct Option: B
Question 7: What can be inferred about the structure of a cell membrane based on the results of Gorter and Grendel's experiment? Options: A. It is a single layer of lipids, B. It is a bilayer of lipids, C. It is a triple layer of lipids, D. It is a complex structure composed of multiple layers of lipids and proteins Correct Option: B
Question 8: How does the structure of a cell membrane, as revealed by Gorter and Grendel's experiment, relate to its function? Options: A. The bilayer structure provides rigidity and support to the cell, B. The bilayer structure allows for easy passage of materials in and out of the cell, C. The bilayer structure provides a balance between stability and fluidity, enabling the cell membrane to regulate the flow of materials, D. The bilayer structure has no relation to the cell membrane's function Correct Option: C
Question 9: What can be said about the significance of Gorter and Grendel's experiment in the context of scientific discovery? Options: A. It was a minor contribution to the understanding of cell membrane structure, B. It was a groundbreaking experiment that provided deep insight into the basic architecture of the cell, C. It was a failed experiment that did not yield any meaningful results, D. It was a redundant experiment that confirmed existing knowledge about cell membranes Correct Option: B
Question 10: How does the discovery of the cell membrane's bilayer structure, as revealed by Gorter and Grendel's experiment, compare to other significant scientific discoveries in the field of biology? Options: A. It was a relatively minor discovery compared to the elucidation of the double-helix structure of DNA, B. It was a major discovery that preceded and laid the groundwork for the elucidation of the double-helix structure of DNA, C. It was a discovery that contradicted the existing understanding of cell membrane structure, D. It was a discovery that had no impact on the field of biology Correct Option: B

But since Question 7 does not have an option that says "Both A and C" or something similar, I would say that Question 5 and Question 7 do not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Every cell in your body is separated from those around it by its outermost layer, its membrane. A cell membrane must be both sturdy and flexible. Imagine a membrane made of metal - great at keeping the cell's guts inside, but horrible at letting materials flow in and out. But a membrane made of fishnet stocking would go too far in the opposite direction - leaky, but easily torn. So, the ideal membrane falls somewhere in the middle. Over the past few centuries, we've learned a lot about the way membranes work. The tale starts in the late 1800's when, according to legend, a German woman named Agnes Pockels was doing dishes. Her observation, that not all detergents dissolve grease in the same way, piqued her curiosity, so she made careful measurements of the size of soapy films that formed on the surface of a metal tray filled with water. Later, in the 1920's, GE scientists Irving Langmuir and Katharine Blodgett reexamined the problem with a more elaborate contraption and found that those tiny slicks were in fact a single layer of oil molecules. Each oil molecule has one side that loves water and floats on the surface, and one side that loathes water and protrudes into the air. So what does it have to do with cell membranes? Well, at the turn of the 20th century, chemists Charles Overton and Hans Meyer demonstrated that the cell membrane is composed of substances that, like oil, have a water-loving part and a water-loathing part. We now call these substances lipids. In 1925, two scientists, Evert Gorter and Francois Grendel, pushed our understanding further. They designed an experiment meant to test whether cell membranes are made of only one layer of lipids, a monolayer, or two layers stacked on top of one another, called a bilayer. Gorter and Grendel drew blood from a dog, a sheep, a rabbit, a goat, a guinea pig, and human volunteers. From each of these samples, they extracted all the lipids from all the red blood cells and placed a few drops of this extract on a tray of water. True to form, the lipids, like oil, spread out into a monolayer, whose size Gorter and Grendel could measure. If they compared the surface area of that monolayer to the surface area to the intact red blood cells, they'd be able to tell whether the red blood cell membrane is one or two layers thick. To understand the design of their experiment, imagine looking down at a sandwich. If you measure the surface area of what you see, you'll get the dimensions of a single slice of bread even though there are two slices, one stacked perfectly atop the other. But, if you open the sandwich and place the two slices side by side, you get twice the surface area. The Gorter and Grendel experiment is basically the same idea. The open sandwich is the monolayer formed by extracted cellular lipids spreading out into a sheet. The closed sandwich is the intact red blood cell membrane. Low and behold, they observed a two-to-one ratio, proving beyond the shadow of a doubt that a cell membrane is a bilayer, which when unstacked, yields a monolayer twice its size. So almost 30 years before the double-helix structure of DNA was elucidated, a single experiment involving fancy versions of household materials enabled deep insight into the basic architecture of the cell.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A cell membrane's construction can be likened to a metal jacket. It's strong and sturdy, keeping all the contents of a cell securely in tact.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary function of a cell membrane in the human body? Options: A. To synthesize proteins, B. To store genetic information, C. To separate the cell from its surroundings and regulate the flow of materials, D. To provide structural support to the cell Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what inspired Agnes Pockels to investigate the properties of soapy films? Options: A. Her work with GE scientists Irving Langmuir and Katharine Blodgett, B. Her observation that not all detergents dissolve grease in the same way while doing dishes, C. Her study of the cell membrane structure, D. Her interest in the double-helix structure of DNA Correct Option: B
Question 3: What would be the consequence of having a cell membrane that is too rigid, like one made of metal? Options: A. It would allow for easy passage of materials in and out of the cell, B. It would provide excellent protection to the cell's contents, C. It would hinder the flow of materials in and out of the cell, D. It would have no effect on the cell's functioning Correct Option: C
Question 4: How do lipids, the primary components of cell membranes, interact with water? Options: A. They are entirely hydrophobic (water-repelling), B. They are entirely hydrophilic (water-attracting), C. They have both hydrophobic and hydrophilic parts, D. They are neutral and do not interact with water Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the main objective of Evert Gorter and Francois Grendel's experiment in 1925? Options: A. To demonstrate the fluidity of cell membranes, B. To determine the structure of DNA, C. To test whether cell membranes are made of one layer (monolayer) or two layers (bilayer) of lipids, D. To study the function of detergents in cell membrane structure Correct Option: C

Question 7: What can be inferred about the structure of a cell membrane based on the results of Gorter and Grendel's experiment? Options: A. It is a single layer of lipids, B. It is a bilayer of lipids, C. It is a triple layer of lipids, D. It is a complex structure composed of multiple layers of lipids and proteins Correct Option: B
Question 8: How does the structure of a cell membrane, as revealed by Gorter and Grendel's experiment, relate to its function? Options: A. The bilayer structure provides rigidity and support to the cell, B. The bilayer structure allows for easy passage of materials in and out of the cell, C. The bilayer structure provides a balance between stability and fluidity, enabling the cell membrane to regulate the flow of materials, D. The bilayer structure has no relation to the cell membrane's function Correct Option: C
Question 9: What can be said about the significance of Gorter and Grendel's experiment in the context of scientific discovery? Options: A. It was a minor contribution to the understanding of cell membrane structure, B. It was a groundbreaking experiment that provided deep insight into the basic architecture of the cell, C. It was a failed experiment that did not yield any meaningful results, D. It was a redundant experiment that confirmed existing knowledge about cell membranes Correct Option: B
Question 10: How does the discovery of the cell membrane's bilayer structure, as revealed by Gorter and Grendel's experiment, compare to other significant scientific discoveries in the field of biology? Options: A. It was a relatively minor discovery compared to the elucidation of the double-helix structure of DNA, B. It was a major discovery that preceded and laid the groundwork for the elucidation of the double-helix structure of DNA, C. It was a discovery that contradicted the existing understanding of cell membrane structure, D. It was a discovery that had no impact on the field of biology Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question addresses the idea presented in the ground truth MCQ, which likens a cell membrane's construction to a metal jacket, stating it's strong and sturdy. However, the ground truth MCQ states this is false because a cell membrane must be both sturdy and flexible. Question 3 presents a similar concept, asking about the consequence of having a cell membrane that is too rigid, like one made of metal, which would hinder the flow of materials in and out of the cell. This aligns with the intent of the ground truth MCQ, making Question 3 the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Blue whales are the largest animals
that have ever roamed the planet. They’re at least two times 
as big as the biggest dinosaurs— “that’s big!“— the length of a basketball court, and as heavy as 40 African elephants. If that’s not enough to make you marvel,
here’s something that will. They’ve grown to this enormous size by feeding exclusively on tiny shrimp-like
creatures called krill— that are no bigger 
than your little finger. In many ways, the sheer size of krill seems to have driven 
the evolution of the blue whale. See, krill are so small
but are found in dense patches. For increased efficiency, blue whales have evolved to use 
a feeding strategy called lunge feeding. Basically, 
the whale accelerates towards a prey patch and opens its mouth wide. To increase the capacity, 
its mouth expands. The special, accordion-like 
blubber layer that extends from its snout 
to its belly button enables the whale to engulf 
large quantities of prey-laden water. With each giant gulp, the whale takes in 125% of its body weight
in water and krill. The whale must then expel the water
while retaining the yummy krill. To do this, it uses its baleen, the comb-like structure made of the same 
stuff our nails and hair are made of, and its tongue. It’s pretty crazy that the blue whale’s 
heart is as big as a small car, a child could crawl through its arteries, its tongue weighs as much as an elephant, but its esophagus is so small, the whale could choke on a loaf of bread. These whales are really not designed 
to feed on anything larger than krill. It’s estimated that blue whales eat 
four tons of krill per day. Because of their incredible design, each dive provides the blue whale 
with 90 times as much energy as is used. Every mouthful of krill provides 
almost 480,000 calories, the same amount you get 
from eating 1,900 hamburgers. But, why are blue whales so big? Blue whales are considerably larger
than the largest living land animal, the elephant. The heavier an animal is, the greater its relative surface area. As weight increases, there’s a point at which the legs 
of that animal would simply collapse. That explains why elephants don’t stand 
on the delicate legs of a horse. They need legs shaped like stout pedestals to hold their bodies up against gravity. In water, the situation 
is quite different. Buoyancy counteracts 
the gravitational pull on the body and their great bulk is therefore 
partially supported by the water. So, the ocean is a great place for species
that want to grow bigger. The other secret to their size
is their diet. By evolving such a huge mouth, the whale’s have specialized to catch 
enormous quantities of highly abundant and nutritious prey, which provides the energy needed 
to grow so big. But, now maybe you’re wondering
why blue whales aren’t any bigger? After all, the ocean sounds like nirvana
for any growing beast. Well, while lunge feeding may 
have allowed blue whales to become the biggest animal 
to have ever roamed the planet, by enabling them to feed efficiently 
in dense prey patches, it isn't cost free. Scientists compared all the costs 
involved with lunge feeding to the energy gained 
from the krill they eat. What they found is that when the whale’s 
body increases in size, the energy that body demands rises faster than the extra energy they get 
from their food. Feeding whales needs 15 times the energy 
required to remain still and 5 times more energy 
than used when swimming. Calculations show that the largest 
a lunge feeder can grow is 33 meters, pretty much blue whale size. Turns out blue whales have a lot
to thank krill for: neat, evolutionary adaptations that would 
not have been possible if krill were not so small. It’s incredible that these tiny creatures 
have allowed blue whales to really push the limits 
of size on our planet. Makes you wonder if that old adage, 
“you are what you eat,” really does apply in blue whale world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Blue whales are the largest animals to have ever lived on the planet. They are at least ________ the biggest dinosaurs.
Options: A. two times larger than, B. as big as, C. 60 times the size of, D. five times larger than
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate length of a blue whale? Options: A. The length of a football field, B. The length of a basketball court, C. The length of a tennis court, D. The length of a swimming pool Correct Option: B
Question 2: What feeding strategy do blue whales use to consume krill? Options: A. They use their baleen to filter small fish from the water., B. They accelerate towards a prey patch and open their mouth wide to engulf large quantities of prey-laden water., C. They use their tongue to catch individual krill., D. They swim slowly through the water with their mouths open. Correct Option: B
Question 3: What might happen if a blue whale were to feed on larger prey? Options: A. Its esophagus would expand to accommodate the larger food., B. Its tongue would become stronger to handle the larger prey., C. It could choke on the larger food due to its small esophagus., D. Its baleen would become more efficient at filtering larger prey. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the estimated daily krill consumption of a blue whale? Options: A. 1 ton, B. 4 tons, C. 10 tons, D. 20 tons Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why are blue whales able to grow larger than the largest living land animal, the elephant? Options: A. Because they have stronger legs., B. Because they have a more efficient feeding strategy., C. Because buoyancy in water counteracts the gravitational pull on their bodies., D. Because they have a larger heart. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the main reason why blue whales are not even bigger than they currently are? Options: A. Because they have reached the maximum size allowed by their skeletal structure., B. Because the energy demands of their body rise faster than the extra energy they get from their food as they increase in size., C. Because they have reached the maximum size allowed by their skin., D. Because they have reached the maximum size allowed by their muscles. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What happens to a blue whale's energy expenditure as it increases in size? Options: A. Its energy expenditure decreases., B. Its energy expenditure remains the same., C. Its energy expenditure increases, but at a slower rate than the extra energy gained from food., D. Its energy expenditure increases faster than the extra energy gained from food. Correct Option: D
Question 8: How does the size of krill influence the evolution of blue whales? Options: A. The small size of krill has driven the evolution of larger blue whales with specialized feeding strategies., B. The small size of krill has driven the evolution of smaller blue whales., C. The large size of krill has driven the evolution of larger blue whales., D. The size of krill has no influence on the evolution of blue whales. Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is unique about the way blue whales use their baleen? Options: A. They use it to filter small fish from the water., B. They use it to catch individual krill., C. They use it to expel water while retaining krill., D. They use it to swim faster through the water. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the relationship between the size of blue whales and their diet of krill? Options: A. The small size of krill has allowed blue whales to evolve into smaller animals., B. The small size of krill has driven the evolution of larger blue whales with specialized feeding strategies., C. The large size of krill has driven the evolution of larger blue whales., D. There is no relationship between the size of blue whales and their diet of krill. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, based on the overall intent and topic, I would say that Question 1 is the most similar.

Although Question 1 does not ask about the size comparison between blue whales and dinosaurs, it does ask about the size of blue whales, which is related to the ground truth MCQ. However, if I had to choose an index, I would say that none of the generated MCQs are a good match.

But if I really had to choose, I would say: 
 Question 1

have allowed blue whales to really push the limits 
of size on our planet. Makes you wonder if that old adage, 
“you are what you eat,” really does apply in blue whale world.

Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

but are found in dense patches. For increased efficiency, blue whales have evolved to use

large quantities of prey-laden water. With each giant gulp, the whale takes in 125% of its body weight
in water and krill. The whale must then expel the water
while retaining the yummy krill. To do this, it uses its baleen, the comb-like structure made of the same 
stuff our nails and hair are made of, and its tongue. It’s pretty crazy that the blue whale’s 
heart is as big as a small car, a child could crawl through its arteries, its tongue weighs as much as an elephant, but its esophagus is so small, the whale could choke on a loaf of bread. These whales are really not designed 
to feed on anything larger than krill. It’s estimated that blue whales eat 
four tons of krill per day. Because of their incredible design, each dive provides the blue whale 
with 90 times as much energy as is used. Every mouthful of krill provides 
almost 480,000 calories, the same amount you get 
from eating 1,900 hamburgers. But, why are blue whales so big? Blue whales are considerably larger
than the largest living land animal, the elephant. The heavier an animal is, the greater its relative surface area. As weight increases, there’s a point at which the legs 
of that animal would simply collapse. That explains why elephants don’t stand 
on the delicate legs of a horse. They need legs shaped like stout pedestals to hold their bodies up against gravity. In water, the situation 
is quite different. Buoyancy counteracts 
the gravitational pull on the body and their great bulk is therefore 
partially supported by the water. So, the ocean is a great place for species
that want to grow bigger. The other secret to their size
is their diet. By evolving such a huge mouth, the whale’s have specialized to catch 
enormous quantities of highly abundant and nutritious prey, which provides the energy needed 
to grow so big. But, now maybe you’re wondering
why blue whales aren’t any bigger? After all, the ocean sounds like nirvana
for any growing beast. Well, while lunge feeding may 
have allowed blue whales to become the biggest animal 
to have ever roamed the planet, by enabling them to feed efficiently 
in dense prey patches, it isn't cost free. Scientists compared all the costs 
involved with lunge feeding to the energy gained 
from the krill they eat. What they found is that when the whale’s 
body increases in size, the energy that body demands rises faster than the extra energy they get 
from their food. Feeding whales needs 15 times the energy 
required to remain still and 5 times more energy 
than used when swimming. Calculations show that the largest 
a lunge feeder can grow is 33 meters, pretty much blue whale size. Turns out blue whales have a lot
to thank krill for: neat, evolutionary adaptations that would 
not have been possible if krill were not so small. It’s incredible that these tiny creatures 
have allowed blue whales to really push the limits 
of size on our planet. Makes you wonder if that old adage, 
“you are what you eat,” really does apply in blue whale world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What percentage of body weight does the whale take in with each gulp, and how is this possible?
Options: A. 100%; its mouth stretches the length of it's body, B. 50%; its mouth is about the size of a swimming pool, C. 125%; its accordion-like mouth stretches to its bellybutton, D. 150%; its jaws open much like that of a snake
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate length of a blue whale? Options: A. The length of a football field, B. The length of a basketball court, C. The length of a tennis court, D. The length of a swimming pool Correct Option: B
Question 2: What feeding strategy do blue whales use to consume krill? Options: A. They use their baleen to filter small fish from the water., B. They accelerate towards a prey patch and open their mouth wide to engulf large quantities of prey-laden water., C. They use their tongue to catch individual krill., D. They swim slowly through the water with their mouths open. Correct Option: B
Question 3: What might happen if a blue whale were to feed on larger prey? Options: A. Its esophagus would expand to accommodate the larger food., B. Its tongue would become stronger to handle the larger prey., C. It could choke on the larger food due to its small esophagus., D. Its baleen would become more efficient at filtering larger prey. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the estimated daily krill consumption of a blue whale? Options: A. 1 ton, B. 4 tons, C. 10 tons, D. 20 tons Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why are blue whales able to grow larger than the largest living land animal, the elephant? Options: A. Because they have stronger legs., B. Because they have a more efficient feeding strategy., C. Because buoyancy in water counteracts the gravitational pull on their bodies., D. Because they have a larger heart. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the main reason why blue whales are not even bigger than they currently are? Options: A. Because they have reached the maximum size allowed by their skeletal structure., B. Because the energy demands of their body rise faster than the extra energy they get from their food as they increase in size., C. Because they have reached the maximum size allowed by their skin., D. Because they have reached the maximum size allowed by their muscles. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What happens to a blue whale's energy expenditure as it increases in size? Options: A. Its energy expenditure decreases., B. Its energy expenditure remains the same., C. Its energy expenditure increases, but at a slower rate than the extra energy gained from food., D. Its energy expenditure increases faster than the extra energy gained from food. Correct Option: D
Question 8: How does the size of krill influence the evolution of blue whales? Options: A. The small size of krill has driven the evolution of larger blue whales with specialized feeding strategies., B. The small size of krill has driven the evolution of smaller blue whales., C. The large size of krill has driven the evolution of larger blue whales., D. The size of krill has no influence on the evolution of blue whales. Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is unique about the way blue whales use their baleen? Options: A. They use it to filter small fish from the water., B. They use it to catch individual krill., C. They use it to expel water while retaining krill., D. They use it to swim faster through the water. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the relationship between the size of blue whales and their diet of krill? Options: A. The small size of krill has allowed blue whales to evolve into smaller animals., B. The small size of krill has driven the evolution of larger blue whales with specialized feeding strategies., C. The large size of krill has driven the evolution of larger blue whales., D. There is no relationship between the size of blue whales and their diet of krill. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

A closer match would be a question that addresses both the feeding strategy and the percentage of body weight. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 4

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Blue whales are the largest animals
that have ever roamed the planet. They’re at least two times 
as big as the biggest dinosaurs— “that’s big!“— the length of a basketball court, and as heavy as 40 African elephants. If that’s not enough to make you marvel,
here’s something that will. They’ve grown to this enormous size by feeding exclusively on tiny shrimp-like
creatures called krill— that are no bigger 
than your little finger. In many ways, the sheer size of krill seems to have driven 
the evolution of the blue whale. See, krill are so small
but are found in dense patches. For increased efficiency, blue whales have evolved to use 
a feeding strategy called lunge feeding. Basically, 
the whale accelerates towards a prey patch and opens its mouth wide. To increase the capacity, 
its mouth expands. The special, accordion-like 
blubber layer that extends from its snout 
to its belly button enables the whale to engulf 
large quantities of prey-laden water. With each giant gulp, the whale takes in 125% of its body weight
in water and krill. The whale must then expel the water
while retaining the yummy krill. To do this, it uses its baleen, the comb-like structure made of the same 
stuff our nails and hair are made of, and its tongue. It’s pretty crazy that the blue whale’s 
heart is as big as a small car, a child could crawl through its arteries, its tongue weighs as much as an elephant, but its esophagus is so small, the whale could choke on a loaf of bread. These whales are really not designed 
to feed on anything larger than krill. It’s estimated that blue whales eat 
four tons of krill per day. Because of their incredible design, each dive provides the blue whale 
with 90 times as much energy as is used. Every mouthful of krill provides 
almost 480,000 calories, the same amount you get 
from eating 1,900 hamburgers. But, why are blue whales so big? Blue whales are considerably larger
than the largest living land animal, the elephant. The heavier an animal is, the greater its relative surface area. As weight increases, there’s a point at which the legs 
of that animal would simply collapse. That explains why elephants don’t stand 
on the delicate legs of a horse. They need legs shaped like stout pedestals to hold their bodies up against gravity. In water, the situation 
is quite different. Buoyancy counteracts 
the gravitational pull on the body and their great bulk is therefore 
partially supported by the water. So, the ocean is a great place for species
that want to grow bigger. The other secret to their size
is their diet. By evolving such a huge mouth, the whale’s have specialized to catch 
enormous quantities of highly abundant and nutritious prey, which provides the energy needed 
to grow so big. But, now maybe you’re wondering
why blue whales aren’t any bigger? After all, the ocean sounds like nirvana
for any growing beast. Well, while lunge feeding may 
have allowed blue whales to become the biggest animal 
to have ever roamed the planet, by enabling them to feed efficiently 
in dense prey patches, it isn't cost free. Scientists compared all the costs 
involved with lunge feeding to the energy gained 
from the krill they eat. What they found is that when the whale’s 
body increases in size, the energy that body demands rises faster than the extra energy they get 
from their food. Feeding whales needs 15 times the energy 
required to remain still and 5 times more energy 
than used when swimming. Calculations show that the largest 
a lunge feeder can grow is 33 meters, pretty much blue whale size. Turns out blue whales have a lot
to thank krill for: neat, evolutionary adaptations that would 
not have been possible if krill were not so small. It’s incredible that these tiny creatures 
have allowed blue whales to really push the limits 
of size on our planet. Makes you wonder if that old adage, 
“you are what you eat,” really does apply in blue whale world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Every mouthful of krill provides the blue whale with _______ calories (the same amount you would get from eating _______ hamburgers).
Options: A. 250,000; 10,250, B. 480,000; 1,900, C. 100,000; 150, D. 370,000; 4,700
Correct Option: B

They swim slowly through the water with their mouths open. Correct Option: B

Its tongue would become stronger to handle the larger prey., C. It could choke on the larger food due to its small esophagus., D. Its baleen would become more efficient at filtering larger prey. Correct Option: C

Because they have a more efficient feeding strategy., C. Because buoyancy in water counteracts the gravitational pull on their bodies., D. Because they have a larger heart. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the main reason why blue whales are not even bigger than they currently are? Options: A. Because they have reached the maximum size allowed by their skeletal structure., B. Because the energy demands of their body rise faster than the extra energy they get from their food as they increase in size., C. Because they have reached the maximum size allowed by their skin., D. Because they have reached the maximum size allowed by their muscles. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What happens to a blue whale's energy expenditure as it increases in size? Options: A. Its energy expenditure decreases., B. Its energy expenditure remains the same., C. Its energy expenditure increases, but at a slower rate than the extra energy gained from food., D. Its energy expenditure increases faster than the extra energy gained from food. Correct Option: D
Question 8: How does the size of krill influence the evolution of blue whales? Options: A. The small size of krill has driven the evolution of larger blue whales with specialized feeding strategies., B. The small size of krill has driven the evolution of smaller blue whales., C. The large size of krill has driven the evolution of larger blue whales., D. The size of krill has no influence on the evolution of blue whales. Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is unique about the way blue whales use their baleen? Options: A. They use it to filter small fish from the water., B. They use it to catch individual krill., C. They use it to expel water while retaining krill., D. They use it to swim faster through the water. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the relationship between the size of blue whales and their diet of krill? Options: A. The small size of krill has allowed blue whales to evolve into smaller animals., B. The small size of krill has driven the evolution of larger blue whales with specialized feeding strategies., C. The large size of krill has driven the evolution of larger blue whales., D. There is no relationship between the size of blue whales and their diet of krill. Correct Option: B

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Blue whales are the largest animals
that have ever roamed the planet. They’re at least two times 
as big as the biggest dinosaurs— “that’s big!“— the length of a basketball court, and as heavy as 40 African elephants. If that’s not enough to make you marvel,
here’s something that will. They’ve grown to this enormous size by feeding exclusively on tiny shrimp-like
creatures called krill— that are no bigger 
than your little finger. In many ways, the sheer size of krill seems to have driven 
the evolution of the blue whale. See, krill are so small
but are found in dense patches. For increased efficiency, blue whales have evolved to use 
a feeding strategy called lunge feeding. Basically, 
the whale accelerates towards a prey patch and opens its mouth wide. To increase the capacity, 
its mouth expands. The special, accordion-like 
blubber layer that extends from its snout 
to its belly button enables the whale to engulf 
large quantities of prey-laden water. With each giant gulp, the whale takes in 125% of its body weight
in water and krill. The whale must then expel the water
while retaining the yummy krill. To do this, it uses its baleen, the comb-like structure made of the same 
stuff our nails and hair are made of, and its tongue. It’s pretty crazy that the blue whale’s 
heart is as big as a small car, a child could crawl through its arteries, its tongue weighs as much as an elephant, but its esophagus is so small, the whale could choke on a loaf of bread. These whales are really not designed 
to feed on anything larger than krill. It’s estimated that blue whales eat 
four tons of krill per day. Because of their incredible design, each dive provides the blue whale 
with 90 times as much energy as is used. Every mouthful of krill provides 
almost 480,000 calories, the same amount you get 
from eating 1,900 hamburgers. But, why are blue whales so big? Blue whales are considerably larger
than the largest living land animal, the elephant. The heavier an animal is, the greater its relative surface area. As weight increases, there’s a point at which the legs 
of that animal would simply collapse. That explains why elephants don’t stand 
on the delicate legs of a horse. They need legs shaped like stout pedestals to hold their bodies up against gravity. In water, the situation 
is quite different. Buoyancy counteracts 
the gravitational pull on the body and their great bulk is therefore 
partially supported by the water. So, the ocean is a great place for species
that want to grow bigger. The other secret to their size
is their diet. By evolving such a huge mouth, the whale’s have specialized to catch 
enormous quantities of highly abundant and nutritious prey, which provides the energy needed 
to grow so big. But, now maybe you’re wondering
why blue whales aren’t any bigger? After all, the ocean sounds like nirvana
for any growing beast. Well, while lunge feeding may 
have allowed blue whales to become the biggest animal 
to have ever roamed the planet, by enabling them to feed efficiently 
in dense prey patches, it isn't cost free. Scientists compared all the costs 
involved with lunge feeding to the energy gained 
from the krill they eat. What they found is that when the whale’s 
body increases in size, the energy that body demands rises faster than the extra energy they get 
from their food. Feeding whales needs 15 times the energy 
required to remain still and 5 times more energy 
than used when swimming. Calculations show that the largest 
a lunge feeder can grow is 33 meters, pretty much blue whale size. Turns out blue whales have a lot
to thank krill for: neat, evolutionary adaptations that would 
not have been possible if krill were not so small. It’s incredible that these tiny creatures 
have allowed blue whales to really push the limits 
of size on our planet. Makes you wonder if that old adage, 
“you are what you eat,” really does apply in blue whale world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Based on scientific research, what is the largest a lunge feeder can grow?
Options: A. 13 meters, B. 33 meters, C. 53 meters, D. 73 meters
Correct Option: B
